thread.title: Goldman Sachs, Citigroup Trading Chopped By Choppy Stocks GS C - Investors.com
thread.title_full: Goldman Sachs, Citigroup Trading Chopped By Choppy Stocks GS C - Investors.com

author: yahoo
title: Goldman Sachs, Citigroup Trading Chopped By Choppy Stocks GS C - Investors.com
text:
S tocks' roller-coaster third quarter — punctuated by a "Black Monday" in August — hurt Wall Street banks' performance in Q3, as Goldman Sachs (NYSE: GS ) and Citigroup (NYSE: C ) joined JPMorgan Chase (NYSE: JPM ) and Bank of America (NYSE: BAC ) in reporting lower trading revenue. 
Goldman, which has the most Wall Street exposure of any of the biggest U.S. banks, earned $2.90 a share in Q3, down 36.3% from a year earlier and missing by a penny estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue fell 18.3% to $6.9 billion, missing views of $7.1 billion. That's the third time in four quarters that Goldman's revenue has declined. 
The volatile markets, fueled by concerns of slowdowns in China and other emerging markets, hurt a number of Goldman Sachs units during the quarter. Institutional client services revenue fell 15% to $3.2 billion. Fixed-income, currencies and commodities tumbled by one-third to $1.5 billion. Equities trading revenue rose 9% to $1.8 billion.   View Enlarged Image 

Investment-management revenue fell 3% to $1.4 billion. 
Investment-banking revenue continued to be a strong point for Goldman, climbing 6% to $1.6 billion. Financial-advisory revenues soared 36% to $809 million as Goldman remained one of Wall Street's top banks for mergers and acquisitions. 
Total underwriting fell 14% to $747 million. Equity underwriting plunged 55% to $190 million, as fees on initial public offerings and stock sales declined. Debt underwriting rose 25% to $557 million. 
Goldman's expenses fell 5% to $4.8 billion. 
Return on equity was 7% in Q3. Total assets under supervision rose 3% to $1.2 trillion as of Sept. 30. 
Goldman shares rose 1.4% to 181.95 in early afternoon trading in the stock market today . Its current IBD Composite Rating is 47, meaning it is being outperformed by 53% of other publicly traded companies. 
Citigroup Legal Costs Dive 
Citigroup also was impacted by choppy stocks, though it benefited from favorable comparisons to the year-earlier period, when it had to restate earnings due to mammoth legal costs. 
The New York-based bank earned $1.28 in Q3, up 13.9% from a year earlier, topping estimates by 3 cents. Net income jumped 51% to $4.3 billion, thanks to significantly lower legal expenses. Revenue fell 7.4% to $18.496 billion, missing views for $18.541 billion. That's the seventh time in eight quarters that Citigroup's revenue has fallen. 
Operating expenses dropped 18% to $10.7 billion, with Citigroup joining Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America in cutting costs as business flagged. 
Citigroup's overall trading revenue slipped 7% to $3.6 billion, slightly worse than the bank had forecast last month. JPMorgan Chase reported a 6% decline in trading revenue, while Bank of America trading revenue fell 4%.
